explanations.A: It looks like you have ignored the fraction and instead worked out 3 x -6. Try writing the -6 as a fraction and have another go.
explanations.B: It looks like you have tried to multiply both the numerator and the denominator by -6. It may help to write the number -6 as a fraction. We can write -6 as -6/1.
explanations.C: ⅓ ✕ (−6) can be thought of as ⅓ ✕ (−6/1). Multiplying out the numerators gives 1 ✕ (−6) = −6, and the denominators gives 3 ✕ 1 = 3. Putting these together gives −6/3 or −6 ÷ 3 = −2. You could also think of this as 1/3 "of" -6. So -6 divided by 3 gives us -2.
explanations.D: It looks like you have treated the -6 as the denominator. If we were to write -6 as a fraction it would become -6/1

explanations.B: It looks like you have treated the -16 as the denominator. If we were to write -16 as a fraction it would become -16/1

explanations.A: 0.5 has the same value as 1/2 so you have not actually changed the number. We can change division to multiplication if we then take the reciprocal of the divisor. Can you remember what the reciprocal of 1/2 is?
explanations.B: Not quite. It looks like you have found 1/2 of -5. Remember "of" means multiply and here we want to divide. Can you remember the method for dividing by a fraction?
explanations.C: To divide by a fraction, change the sign to multiplication and then flip (take the reciprocal of) the fraction. So in this case, ÷ 1/2 becomes ✕ 2/1 or just ✕ 2.
explanations.D: Maybe you don't think it is possible to find 1/2 of 5. Here we are actually trying to divide -5 by 1/2, not multiply. Can you remember the method for dividing by a fraction?

explanations.A: To divide by a fraction, change the sign to multiplication and then flip (take the reciprocal of) the fraction. So in this case, ÷ 1/3 becomes ✕ 3/1 or just ✕ 3.
explanations.B: It looks like you have attempted to rewrite ⅓. As we are multiplying rather than dividing then we need to change the divisor in some way. We can change division to multiplication if we then take the reciprocal of the divisor. Can you remember what the reciprocal of ⅓ is?
explanations.C: Not quite. It looks like you have found 1/3 of -12. Remember "of" means multiply and here we want to divide. Can you remember the method for dividing by a fraction?
explanations.D: It looks like you have forgotten how to divide by a fraction. We can change division to multiplication if we then take the reciprocal of the divisor. Can you remember what the reciprocal of ⅓ is?

explanations.A: It looks like you have worked out -12 subtract -4. Here we want to divide 12 by -4. First think about 12 divided by 4 and then consider what effect the negative sign will have.
explanations.B: It looks like you have worked out 12 subtract -4. Here we want to divide 12 by -4. First think about 12 divided by 4 and then consider what effect the negative sign will have.
explanations.C: The calculation 12 ÷ (−4) is the same as (＋12) ÷ (−4), so we have unlike signs, meaning the answer will be negative, so −3. If you have worked with negative counters before then remember when we divide by a negative we "flip" those positive counters over to become negative.
explanations.D: It looks like you have correctly worked out 12 divided by 4, but we now need to consider what effect the negative sign will have.

explanations.C: It looks like you have worked out 21 subtract -3. Here we want to divide 21 by -3. First think about 21 divided by 3 and then consider what effect the negative sign will have.
explanations.D: It looks like you have worked out -21 subtract 3. Here we want to divide 21 by -3. First think about 21 divided by 3 and then consider what effect the negative sign will have.

explanations.A: It looks like you may have struggled to divide by 1/4. Remember that we can change division to multiplication if we take the reciprocal of the divisor. Can you remember what the reciprocal of 1/4 is?
explanations.B: It looks like you may have struggled to divide by -1/4. Remember that we can change division to multiplication if we take the reciprocal of the divisor. Also consider what happens when we divide by a negative.
explanations.C: Let's work out the top line first: (−2) ✕ (−6). The signs are the same (like signs) so the answer will be positive, so ＋12. Now we have 12/(−0.25) or 12 ÷ (−0.25) or 12 ÷ (−¼). This is the same as (＋12) ✕ (−4). This calculation has unlike signs, so the answer will be −48.
explanations.D: Not quite! Have another go, but pay close attention to the sign of each number. Work out the top half of the fraction first, including what sign it will have.

explanations.A: Let's work out the top line first: (−3) ✕ (−2). The signs are the same (like signs) so the answer will be positive, so ＋6. Now we have 6/(−0.2) or 6 ÷ (−0.2) or 6/1 ÷ (−2/10). This is the same as (＋6/1) ✕ (−10/2). This calculation has unlike signs, so the answer will be negative. Multiplying both numerators gives −60, and both denominators gives 2. This gives −60/2 = −30.
explanations.B: It looks like you have divided by -2, rather than -0.2. Try writing -0.2 as a fraction and use your knowledge about dividing by a fraction to help you work out the answer
explanations.C: Nearly there! Have another go, but pay close attention to the sign of each number. Work out the top half of the fraction first, including what sign it will have. If you are multiplying 2 fractions together then look at the sign of the fractions before you multiply in order to work out what sign your answer will have.
explanations.D: It looks like you have divided by -2, rather than -0.2 and maybe made a negative error. Try writing -0.2 as a fraction and use your knowledge about dividing by a fraction to help you work out the answer. Pay close attention to the signs at each stage to work out whether your answer will be positive or negative.

explanations.A: (−5)^2 is the same as (−5) ✕ (−5) = ＋25 (because of like signs). Also, −5 − (−20) = −5 ＋ 20 = 15. So we have 25 > 15.
explanations.B: I think you may have made a mistake working out −5 − (−20). Subtracting a negative is the same as adding its additive inverse. So subtracting -20 is the same as adding +20
explanations.C: You may have made a mistake when working out (-5)². Write it out as -5 x -5 and try again
explanations.D: Not quite. This symbol means that the right hand side is greater than or equal to the left hand side. Is this true?

explanations.A: (-3)² = 9, and -6 - -3 = -6 + 3 = -3. 9 is greater than -3, so we use >
explanations.B: Not quite. Remember that when we take away a negative it is the same as adding a positive. Also, (-3)² = -3 x -3
explanations.C: Not quite. Remember that when we take away a negative it is the same as adding a positive. Also, (-3)² = -3 x -3
explanations.D: Not quite. This symbol means that the right hand side and left hand side are always equal. Is this true?
